title: Bernardo Duque
text:
I am an Economics PhD Student at Brown University interested in Development Economics and Political Economy. In particular, my research focuses on Crime and Criminal Organizations, which pose significant challenges to development in my country.
In addition to my academic pursuits, I am also interested in addressing these issues on a practical level. I co-founded an NGO dedicated to scientific dissemination in my hometown, Rio de Janeiro, and I have also gained valuable experience working in the private and public sector.

Experience
I have worked as an research assistant in several projects since 2020. Some of the topics of these projects are the effects of pretrial detention arrest on recidivism; the expasion of drug-trafficking organizations in Rio; the investigation of some predictions of the median voter theorem; and the study of whether politicians keep their campaign promises after being elected.
I have also worked in the public sector as a data analyst for the Research Center at the Public’s Attorney’s Office of Rio de Janeiro. I assisted research on militias and drug-trafficking organizations in Rio.
Further, I have experience in the private sector for consulting firms in Brazil, where I worked on projects related to economic analysis and policy evaluation.

title: Research
text:
Who Becomes a Criminal? (Master’s Thesis)
April, 2024
We investigate selection into criminality. Specifically, we use a noveldataset on inmates across 24 of 26 Brazilian states and rich administrative data to draw the profiles of criminals born between 1996 and 2002. We compare them with non-criminal individuals from the same cohort using a linearprobability model with year of birth and place fixed effects. Our findings suggest that criminals come from more urban and vulnerable places, with a higher exposure to other criminals. In addition, our results indicate that family structure matters and that parents of criminals are more economically vulnerable than parents of non-criminals. Finally, criminals have worse educational performance, a history of juvenile detention, and worse labor market performance.
